"You have Elite-rank strength with solid fundamentals," I assessed. "Your combat experience needs significant work, but that will come naturally with time and practise. Focus on understanding your ice bloodline’s properties more deeply - that’s where your true advantages will emerge."
"Thank you for the guidance," Kael said sincerely.
"The academy will push you harder than this," I warned. "But if you maintain this learning attitude, you’ll adapt quickly."
Later that afternoon, I found my mother in the estate’s garden, tending to some rare magical plants that required careful cultivation. She looked up when I approached, setting aside her gardening tools.
"How was your session with Kael?" she asked, already knowing I’d been evaluating him.
"Promising. He has legitimate Elite-rank strength and a strong ice bloodline. With proper training, he’ll perform well at the academy." I sat on a nearby bench, watching her work. "How are you holding up with Father gone?"
My mother’s hands paused briefly before continuing their careful movements. "I’ve been through this before. Your father has embarked on dangerous missions throughout our marriage. Each time, I worry. Each time, he returns."
"Indeed."
She looked at me directly, her maternal intuition clearly sensing something. "You know something you’re not telling me. That’s why you gave him those valuable items."
I chose my words carefully. "I have... sources that suggest this mission carries unusual risks. Political complications beyond just the monster threat."
My mother nodded slowly, unsurprised. "Your father suspected as much. That’s why he assembled such a substantial force despite the Crown’s support." She returned to her plants, though her movements had become more mechanical. "Tell me, Adrian - honestly - do you believe he’ll return?"
"Yes," I answered without hesitation. "The odds aren’t perfect, but they’re acceptable. Father is too skilled and too prepared to fall to a simple ambush, even one disguised as a royal mission."
She smiled faintly. "Good, you need to believe in your father. Adrian, you know you’ve changed so much since your awakening. The old Adrian would never have been so direct about such serious matters."
"The old Adrian was foolish in many ways. I’m trying to be better."
In a calm, motherly tone she said. "You’re succeeding, your father is proud of you, even if he doesn’t always express it too much. Sponsoring Kael’s admission, improving your combat abilities, winning your examination so decisively - these are achievements that reflect well on our family."
We sat in comfortable silence for a while, the afternoon sun casting long shadows across the garden. Despite the underlying worry about my father’s mission, there was peace in this moment.
"Stay for dinner," my mother suggested. "Kael would appreciate more time with you, and I’d enjoy the company."
"I’d like that," I agreed.
The estate felt different with my father gone, but not emptier. Instead, it reinforced the importance of the connections I was building - with Kael, with my mother, with the future I was trying to shape through knowledge and careful intervention.
Fifty-nine percent survival odds for my father. It would have to be enough, because I’d done everything within my current power to improve those chances. Now came the harder part - waiting and trusting that preparation would prove sufficient when the critical moment arrived.
The next day arrived with quiet morning light filtering through the estate windows. I had decided to remain another day, wanting to keep my mother company while my father travelled toward what could be his most dangerous mission yet.
We shared breakfast together in the smaller dining room rather than the formal hall - a more intimate setting that felt appropriate given the circumstances. My mother spoke about estate management, upcoming social obligations, and various mundane matters that provided comfortable distraction from heavier concerns.
"The Rosewood family has invited us to their summer gathering," she mentioned while reviewing correspondence. "Though given your father’s absence, I’ll likely decline or send regrets."
"You should still attend if you want to, I will accompany you if you want." I suggested.
She flashed me a smile before nodding. "Perhaps. We’ll see how matters develop."
Throughout the morning, I accompanied her on various activities around the estate - reviewing accounts with the workers, inspecting the gardens, discussing menu planning with the head cook. The domestic routines provided grounding normalcy that we both appreciated.
As afternoon approached, I felt the familiar notification pulse in my consciousness that indicated my daily reward had become available.
[Daily Login Available!]
[Would you like to claim your daily reward?]
I mentally selected yes while maintaining my conversation with my mother, hoping for something more useful than the disappointing items I’d received over the past five days.
The previous rewards had been frustratingly mundane - basic healing potions, common herbs, low-grade equipment that offered no improvements over what I already possessed. It felt like the system was cycling through filler content rather than providing genuinely valuable acquisitions.
This time, I hoped the pattern would break and deliver something substantial that could contribute meaningfully to my various development priorities or the challenges ahead.

chapters.title: Chapter 135: Mysterious Egg
chapters.content:
Chapter 135: Mysterious Egg
[Congratulations! You have received: Mysterious Egg]
I maintained my composure during the conversation with my mother, though internally my attention had completely shifted to the notification. The reward description was intriguing enough that I needed to examine it privately as soon as possible.
"Mother, I think I’ll retire to my room for a bit," I said casually after we finished reviewing the week’s accounts. "I want to go through some academy materials I brought with me."
"Of course, dear. I’ll be in the solarium if you need anything."
I made my way quickly to my guest chambers and closed the door, activating the privacy wards before summoning the reward from my system space.
What materialized in my hands made my eyes widen considerably.
The egg was approximately the size of a melon, its surface displaying a mesmerizing array of colours that shifted and swirled as I rotated it. Deep purples blended into vibrant crimsons, which transitioned into brilliant golds and oceanic blues. The patterns weren’t static, they moved across the shell like living aurora lights, creating hypnotic displays that suggested powerful magic contained within.
I quickly accessed the detailed information:
[Mysterious Egg]
Rank: King]
[Details: Mysterious egg of an unknown species containing a beast that can reach King rank at maturity.]
My heart raced as the implications sank in. King rank, two full tiers above where my father currently stood. Beasts that could achieve King rank were really powerful creatures, the kind that could reshape battlefields and influence the fate of entire kingdoms. They were all intelligent and some had the trait of talking once they reached a high rank.
The egg felt warm to the touch, and I could sense faint life energy pulsing within. Whatever creature was developing inside was already alive, just waiting for the right conditions to hatch.
I examined the shell more closely, noting intricate patterns that might indicate the species type. The color combinations suggested possible elemental affinities - the crimson and gold might indicate fire or light attributes, while the purple and blue could suggest storm or shadow elements. Without more information, identifying the exact species was impossible.
Questions flooded my mind. What did it need to hatch? How long would the incubation period last? What kind of care would the hatchling require? And most critically - could I trust a King-rank beast to remain loyal once it reached its full potential?
The daily reward system had just provided something that could fundamentally alter my long-term power trajectory. A King-rank companion would be invaluable for the conflicts I knew were coming, assuming I could successfully raise and bond with whatever emerged from this spectacular egg.
I carefully returned it to my system space, my mind already racing through the logistics of managing such a powerful acquisition while maintaining secrecy about its existence.
But first, I needed to understand the hatching requirements.
I retrieved the egg again and examined it from every angle, searching for clues about what conditions might trigger the incubation process. The warm surface suggested it might require heat, but how much? The swirling colors could indicate elemental affinity needs, but which elements specifically?
I tried channeling small amounts of mana into the shell, watching for any reaction. Nothing changed. I attempted blood manipulation, wondering if a blood bond was required for hatching. Still no response.
Then, nearly an hour of my time was spent attempting various approaches - exposing it to different temperatures, trying various enchantment activation phrases, even speaking to it directly in case it responded to verbal commands.
Nothing worked.
Finally, I had to accept that the egg would hatch according to its own timeline and requirements, whatever those might be. Forcing the process could damage the creature inside.
With a sigh, I returned it to my system space once more. Patience would be required.
While the reward was undeniably powerful, it provided no immediate benefits for my current situation. I wasn’t foolish enough to measure value solely by instant utility, a King-rank beast companion would be really powerful once matured, but in the short term, the egg was essentially an investment rather than a power boost.
The rest of the day was spent productively in combat training with the estate’s guards and Kael. My father’s departure had left several Transcendent-rank guards behind to maintain estate security, and I decided to test myself against their capabilities.
The sparring session drew quite an audience as word spread through the garrison that the young master was challenging Transcendent opponents.
"Your footwork has improved dramatically, young master," remarked Captain Deren, one of the senior guards who had served my family for decades. "I remember when you could barely hold a proper stance. Now you’re forcing me to concentrate."
CLASH!
I engaged him with full blood enhancement active, my blade meeting his with strength that clearly surprised him. His eyebrows rose as I pushed through his defensive guard.
"That enhancement technique..." another guard observed from the sidelines. "It’s bridging the entire rank gap. I’ve never seen anything like it."
"The young master’s combat power rivals our own," Another senior guard added with obvious respect. "At Elite rank, no less. Imagine what he’ll be capable of once he advances to Transcendent. He will be able to face commander level threats!"
A smile formed on my face hearing his words, but I didn’t take them seriously. I knew that the higher the rank the higher the gap between them. Whilst I was doing was really impressive, it wasn’t unheard of, the modt takented in the history of the kingdom were able to do so at the peak of elite rank.
I demonstrated the Light Steps technique I’d been practicing, the Royal-rank footwork allowing me to outmaneuver Deren’s counterattacks. His expression showed genuine approval.
"You’ve been training your footwork really well," he concluded after our exchange. "The fluidity and precision aren’t something you develop through basic drills alone."
After sparring the senior guards, I joined the normal trainning session. Honing my swordsmanship skills, footwork, and helping Kael too.

chapters.title: Chapter 136: Elen’s predicament
chapters.content:
Chapter 136: Elen’s predicament
When the sun started to set, casting long shadows across the estate grounds, I decided it was time to return to the academy. I had classes scheduled for the next day and needed to maintain my academic attendance despite the family circumstances.
I found my mother in the sitting room and Kael practicing forms in the training yard to bid them both farewell.
"Travel safely, dear," my mother said, embracing me warmly. "And don’t worry too much about your father. He’s survived worse situations than this."
"I know. But stay vigilant while he’s away. I’ve ordered Lex and Lux to remain at the estate for your protection."
"That’s not necessary," she protested gently. "You need guards at the academy—"
"You need them more than I do," I interrupted firmly. "My combat capabilities are sufficient for academy security, and I have Kojiro available if truly serious threats emerge. The estate is a more likely target while Father is away."
My mother nodded, recognizing the logic even if she worried about my safety.
Kael approached as I prepared to depart. "Thank you again for the training and guidance. I’ll work on the ice manipulation applications you demonstrated."
"Keep practicing. I’ll make the arrangements for your academy admission when I return."
The carriage journey back was uneventful, giving me time to review the day’s events and plan for the coming week. The mysterious egg remained secure in my system space, a powerful secret that would require careful management once it eventually hatched.
Arriving at the academy grounds, I noticed it was quite late - well past the normal curfew hours. The gates were still accessible for students with proper authorization, but the campus was notably quiet compared to daytime activity levels.
As we approached within about two hundred meters of the main entrance, I spotted two figures standing near the gate. The magical lighting revealed Elen’s distinctive blue hair, and she appeared to be in conversation with a middle-aged man I didn’t recognize.
Something about her body language troubled me. Her posture looked defensive and vulnerable in ways I’d never seen before, even during dangerous examination situations.
"Stop the carriage here," I commanded the driver. "I’ll proceed on foot from this point."
"Young master, are you certain—"
"I’ll handle it. You can leave now."
I exited the carriage and walked slowly toward the gate, staying just outside their senses range but close enough for me to hear their discussion.
As I drew nearer, Elen’s frustrated voice carried across the distance.
"Father, until when are they going to embezzle you?!"
The middle-aged man, apparently her father, which made him Baron Brightwater sighed heavily. His clothing was well-made but showed signs of age and repeated mending, suggesting financial constraints unusual for nobility.
"Elen, please understand the position I’m in," he said wearily. "The merchant consortium has been undermining our trade routes for years. Every appeal to higher authorities gets blocked by their political connections."
"Then fight back! Report them to the Duke or even petition the Crown directly!"
"You think I haven’t tried?" His voice carried the exhaustion of someone who had fought and lost repeatedly. "The Brightwater barony doesn’t have the influence to challenge families with Royal Court connections. Our complaints disappear into bureaucratic delays while they continue bleeding our resources."
Elen’s hands clenched into fists. "So what am I supposed to do? You’re asking for my academy points again, aren’t you?"
The Baron’s expression showed guilt and desperation in equal measure. "The points can be converted to gold through. Just fifty thousand points would cover our most urgent debts and buy us time to restructure—"
"Fifty thousand?!" Elen’s voice cracked slightly. "Father, I need those points for training facilities, equipment, materials for my alchemy studies. Without proper resources, I can’t develop my abilities fast enough to actually help our family long-term."
"I know what I’m asking," he said quietly. "But if we don’t address the immediate crisis, there won’t be a long term. The creditors are threatening to petition for administrative receivership of our barony. We could lose everything."
The pieces suddenly clicked into place for me. This explained Elen’s careful consideration when purchasing blacksmithing materials with gold coins at that shop. It explained her hesitation about spending points on the alchemy room despite clearly wanting the practice time. She wasn’t naturally frugal - she was supporting a family on the verge of financial collapse.
"I’ll give you the points," Elen said after a long silence, her voice resigned. "But Father, this can’t continue forever. I’m willing to help - that was my goal in coming to the academy in the first place, to gain abilities that could improve our family’s position. But you need to start doing something too. Find new trade partners, develop alternative revenue sources, anything besides just relying on me to bail out the barony."
"You’re right," the Baron admitted. "I’ve been passive for too long, hoping the situation would somehow resolve itself. That changes now. I promise I’ll be more proactive about finding solutions rather than just managing decline."
Elen then left for a while before coming back with a few large pouches of gold that she pulled out her storage ring.
She had probably converted points to gold. The Baron accepted it with obvious relief mixed with shame.
"Thank you, daughter. I know this is difficult."
"Just... make it count this time," she said softly.
They embraced briefly before the Baron departed, leaving Elen standing alone at the gate with slumped shoulders that spoke of emotional exhaustion.
I remained in the shadows, processing what I’d witnessed and considering whether to reveal my presence or allow her privacy to compose herself.​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​
After a moment I decided to hide my presence, appearing now wasn’t a good idea for my plans.
After her father left, Elen stood there for a while simply staring at the sky adorned with the glittering stars and moon.
Then, out of nowhere she slapped both her cheeks and put on a smile on her face before turning back to head inside the academy with joyfuly energy.

chapters.title: Chapter 137: Blacksmithing
chapters.content:
Chapter 137: Blacksmithing
The next day arrived with my usual early morning routine, blood consumption, trait training, and academy classes. By afternoon, I made my way to the blacksmithing facilities for the optional crafting module that had become one of my most valuable skill development opportunities.
The workshop was already heated when I entered, the massive forge radiating waves of warmth that made the air shimmer. Several other students were scattered throughout the space, working on various projects with varying degrees of competence.
"Blackwood!" A booming voice called out from near the main anvil. "About time you showed up. I was beginning to think you’d abandoned proper craftsmanship for those academy combat drills."
Jan, one of the kingdom’s master blacksmiths and our instructor for the blacksmithing class, was impossible to miss. The elderly man stood nearly as tall as Kojiro despite his advanced age, his frame still packed with the dense muscle that came from decades of working metal. His long white beard reached nearly to his belly button, while his short white hair was perpetually dusted with soot and metal filings. Deep laugh lines creased his face, and his hands, scarred and calloused beyond belief - could shape steel with more precision than most could manage with delicate tools.
"Just had some matters to attend to, Master Jan," I replied respectfully, moving toward my designated workstation.
"some matters," he grumbled, though his eyes showed approval rather than criticism. "At least you have your priorities straight. Too many youngsters these days think combat prowess is everything, ignoring the fundamental truth that civilization is built on craftsmanship, not sword swings."
I couldn’t help but smile at his familiar lecture that he had been repeating for the past few days. Jan had been trying to convince me to abandon combat training entirely since my second blacksmithing session, when he’d realized I possessed genuine Tier 1 capabilities despite being a first-year student in the first semester.
"Speaking of which," Jan continued, approaching my station with surprising speed for someone his age. "Show me what you’ve been working on. And don’t think I didn’t notice those improved skateboard designs circulating through the student body. I asked a few students, apparently that was your work."
"Yes, Master Jan. I refined the propulsion system and durability-"
"Of course you did!" He laughed heartily, slapping the anvil with enough force to make it ring. "The boy has Tier 1 skills, a mind for innovation, and he wastes half his time hitting training dummies during combat practice! It’s a tragedy, I tell you. A proper tragedy!" Jan nudged one of the other students who smiled wryly.
Other students glanced over at Jan’s outburst, some looking envious while others seemed resigned to his un-filtered personality.
I laid out my current project - components for an improved crossbow design that would incorporate more sophisticated mana channeling. "I wanted your advice on the Orichalcum threading patterns. The current configuration works, but I think there’s inefficiency in how the energy flows through the curves."
Jan leaned in close, his experienced eyes immediately identifying the issue I’d been struggling with. "Aha! See, here’s your problem. You’re treating Orichalcum like it’s just conductive wire, but it’s got properties that respond to geometric patterns enhancing its effect. You need to account for the internal structure when planning your threading paths."
He grabbed a piece of chalk and began sketching complex diagrams on the workbench surface, his hands moving with surprising delicacy. "See these angles? Orichalcum conducts mana most efficiently at thirty-seven and sixty-two degree turns. Your curves are creating resistance that bleeds off about fifteen percent of your input energy."
I studied his corrections carefully, immediately recognizing the brilliance of his insight. "So if I redesign the channel pathways to incorporate those specific angles..."
"Exactly! Now you’re thinking like a proper craftsman instead of an academy brat who thinks everything is solved by throwing more mana at problems."
We worked together for the next hour, with Jan providing guidance that went far beyond standard instruction. Of course in this hour, he helped other students too. His knowledge came from decades of practical experience with materials that most blacksmiths never even encountered.
"You’ve got a gift, boy," he said seriously during a break from the intense work. "Real talent that shows up maybe once in a generation. Most students struggle for a whole year to reach Tier 1 competency, whilst some never reach it, but you arrived already possessing those skills. It’s like you were born knowing how metal wants to be shaped."
"I had good foundational training" I deflected, unable to explain that the skills came from a daily reward system.
"Foundational training my aged arse," Jan snorted. "I’ve seen dozens of students with ’good foundations’ who couldn’t shape a decent horseshoe after months of practice. You understand the material on an intuitive level that can’t just be taught."
His voice took on a more serious tone. "That’s why it pains me to see you dividing your focus. If you dedicated yourself fully to blacksmithing, truly dedicated yourself, you could reach Tier 3 before you’re thirty. Maybe even Tier 4 in your lifetime. Do you understand what that means? There are only three Tier 4 blacksmiths in the entire kingdom."
"I appreciate the confidence, Master Jan. But combat skills are necessary for survival in this world."
"Bah! Survival? You’re the son of a Duke! Hire people to do your fighting while you create masterworks that will outlast kingdoms!" Despite his argumentative words, his expression showed he understood my position even if he disagreed with it. "But I suppose youngsters need to make their own mistakes. Just promise me you’ll keep working on your craft alongside all that sword-swinging nonsense."
"Of course. I promise, Master Jan."
Jan nodded his head in approval before turning to help a student that called for him.
Nearby, I could hear other students whispering among themselves, their voices carrying across the workshop despite attempts at discretion.
"Did you hear Master Jan praising Blackwood again? The old man barely acknowledges most of us here, but he treats Adrian like a prized apprentice."

chapters.title: Chapter 138: Surprise Exam!
chapters.content:
Chapter 138: Surprise Exam!
"It’s not fair. He wins the combat examination, breaks academy records, and apparently he’s some kind of blacksmithing prodigy too? How is one person good at everything?"
"I heard he invented that skateboard thing everyone’s talking about. Created it from scratch in a single session."
"Probably inherited talent from his bloodline. Duke bloodline’s must get all sorts of advantages we can’t match."
The envy in their voices was obvious, though I’d grown accustomed to such reactions. Excellence attracted both admiration and resentment in equal measure.
Jan apparently heard them too, because he raised his voice deliberately. "Talent is meaningless without dedication! Half you lot complain about others’ success while spending your workshop time gossiping instead of actually working! Now get back to your projects before I assign remedial hammer swings!"
The students scattered back to their stations with guilty expressions, and Jan winked at me conspiratorially.
"Let them grumble. Jealousy is just recognition that someone else is achieving what they wish they could. Now, show me how you’re planning to integrate those angle corrections."
...
Once the blacksmithing class ended, I made my way to Instructor Sylvia’s classroom along with the rest of my Elite class. The afternoon session typically covered tactical theory and strategic planning, but something about Sylvia’s expression when we entered suggested today would be different.
"Take your seats quickly," she commanded, her tone carrying unusual sharpness. "We’re conducting a surprise written examination today."
The classroom erupted in surprised murmurs and groans. Surprise tests were notoriously difficult to prepare for, and Sylvia’s examinations were known for their comprehensive scope.
"This will be an individual assessment, not a team exercise," she continued, silencing the protests with a raised hand. "The exam covers kingdom history, regional geography, political structures, economic systems, and military theory - all material from our curriculum thus far."
My mind immediately began calculating. Theory-based examinations weren’t my greatest strength. While I possessed knowledge from my previous life and the novel, the specific historical details of this kingdom’s past weren’t always perfectly aligned with what I’d read. I knew the basics and could certainly pass, but passing wasn’t sufficient.
I wanted the highest marks possible. Academic excellence contributed to overall academy rankings and influenced future opportunities.
Sylvia began distributing thick examination booklets while another instructor set up privacy enchantments around each desk - magical barriers that prevented students from easily seeing their neighbors’ papers through casual glances.
"You have two hours," Sylvia announced. "No talking, no unauthorized material access, no communication artifacts. Anyone caught cheating will receive automatic failure and potential disciplinary action."
As she placed the exam on my desk, I quickly scanned the questions. The content was comprehensive and detailed - asking for specific dates of historical treaties, precise geographic coordinates of strategic locations, and nuanced analysis of political decisions made centuries ago.
I knew exactly whose paper I needed to reference.
Elen.
From the novel, I remembered clearly that Elen was the most academically gifted student in our class when it came to written examinations. Her theoretical knowledge was exceptional, developed through long hours of studying. While her combat abilities were still developing, her scholarly capabilities were undeniable.
Secondly, I knew that Elen did not change from my interactions with her. She was still as studious as she had been in the novel.
The challenge was accessing her answers without detection.
The privacy enchantments prevented simple visual observation, but they weren’t designed to stop someone with my particular advantages. My vampire bloodline provided supernatural senses far beyond human norms, and my Physical Enhancement trait could be applied to sensory capabilities as well as combat attributes.
I activated my enhanced vision carefully, channeling just enough power to sharpen my perception without creating obvious magical signatures that Sylvia might detect. The privacy barriers were designed to stop normal sight lines, but enhanced supernatural vision operated on different principles.
Elen sat three rows ahead to the left, not ideal positioning, but workable. I could see her bent over her exam, already writing with confident, precise strokes.
Sylvia began patrolling the classroom with sharp attention, her eyes scanning for any suspicious behavior. She was experienced enough to recognize the subtle signs of cheating - awkward postures, unusual eye movements, hesitation patterns that suggested students were waiting to copy others.
I maintained perfect composure, writing my own answers at a steady pace while simultaneously tracking Elen’s paper with peripheral vision. The key was appearing completely focused on my own work while actually dividing my attention.
Question seven: Describe the Treaty of Thornvale and its impact on regional trade routes.
I’d written a basic response based on general knowledge, but Elen’s answer was far more detailed. She included specific merchant guild names, precise percentage changes in trade volumes, and political ramifications I hadn’t considered.
I carefully incorporated her additional details into my response, rephrasing to avoid exact duplication while capturing the substance of her knowledge.
Sylvia paused near my desk, and I immediately stopped my enhanced observation, focusing entirely on my own paper. She studied me for a moment before moving on, apparently satisfied that I was working legitimately.
Question twelve: Identify the geographic coordinates and strategic importance of the Northern Watch fortresses.
This one was particularly difficult - requiring precise numerical coordinates that I had no way of knowing from general knowledge. Elen was writing them down with confident accuracy, clearly having memorized the data.
I waited until Sylvia moved to the opposite side of the classroom before enhancing my vision again. The coordinates appeared clearly despite the privacy barrier - numbers that I quickly transcribed while maintaining my casual writing posture.
The process was nerve-wracking. Each time I accessed enhanced vision, there was risk of detection. Sylvia was no fool, and prolonged magical enhancement would eventually register on her awareness.
I had to be strategic - copying only the most valuable information, the answers I genuinely couldn’t produce through my own knowledge, while filling the rest with legitimate responses to maintain authenticity.
Question eighteen: Analyze the political factors that led to the Continental Alliance collapse.
This required political understanding that went beyond simple facts.

chapters.title: Chapter 139: Surprise Exam[2]
chapters.content:
Chapter 139: Surprise Exam[2]
Elen’s analysis was brilliant - identifying underlying economic pressures, personality conflicts among leadership, and strategic miscalculations that had contributed to the alliance’s dissolution.
I absorbed her framework and wrote my own version, maintaining enough difference to avoid raising suspicion while benefiting from her superior analytical perspective.
Time continued passing with agonizing slowness. Sylvia’s patrols remained unpredictable, forcing me to constantly adapt my observation timing. Several times, she stopped near students who were struggling, offering no assistance but clearly monitoring for cheating behaviors.
An hour and forty minutes into the examination, I had successfully referenced Elen’s answers for approximately twenty critical questions while genuinely completing the remaining through my own knowledge.
The final twenty minutes, I focused entirely on my own paper, reviewing and refining answers to ensure consistency and quality. No more enhanced vision, no more observation - just legitimate work that would withstand any scrutiny.
"Time is up," Sylvia announced precisely two hours after we’d begun. "Put down your writing instruments and close your examination booklets."
I complied immediately, my heart rate finally beginning to normalize after the sustained tension of covert information gathering.
Sylvia collected the exams personally, her sharp eyes scanning each student’s face as she took their papers. When she reached my desk, she paused fractionally longer than with others.
"Confident in your performance, Adrian?" she asked neutrally.
"I did my best with the material, Instructor," I replied honestly, which was technically true even if the method was questionable.
She nodded and moved on, leaving me uncertain whether she suspected anything or was simply maintaining her vigilance.
As we filed out of the classroom, I caught Elen looking thoughtful, though she couldn’t possibly know I’d been observing her work. The privacy enchantments had functioned as designed from her perspective.
The gamble had been necessary. In the academy’s competitive environment, every advantage mattered, and maintaining top academic standings was just as important as combat excellence for long-term positioning.
All I have to do now was simply wait for the exam results to arrive.
As I walked toward the training facilities following my usual afternoon routine, an unexpected voice called out behind me.
"Wait."
I turned around to find Seraphina walking toward me with her characteristic calm composure. The legendary bloodline user moved with natural grace, her distinctive features drawing attention from other students in the corridor even though she maintained a deliberately low profile.
I stood in place, waiting for her to close the distance while my mind raced through possible motivations for this conversation. Was she fishing for information on behalf of Kyle’s faction? Attempting to assess my capabilities for future confrontations? Or did she have some personal agenda I hadn’t anticipated?
The novel had portrayed her as straightforward and honorable, but circumstances had changed significantly. My interference with the timeline and her elimination might have altered her personality or priorities in ways I couldn’t predict.
"Yes?" I asked neutrally, studying her expression for clues about her intentions.
"I want to talk with you for a minute," she said calmly, her voice carrying none of the hostility I might have expected from someone I’d effectively removed from a major competition.
After a moment of contemplation, I nodded and gestured toward a quieter area of the academy grounds. "This way."
We walked in silence until reaching a secluded courtyard away from the main student traffic. Seraphina positioned herself with typical awareness - maintaining comfortable distance while ensuring clear sight lines in case this conversation turned confrontational.
She started without any preliminary small talk. "Were you hiding your true strength before your awakening?"
"Huh? What do you mean?" I responded, despite knowing what she wanted.
Seraphina’s cold eyes studied me carefully. "During our engagement period, you displayed completely different capabilities and personality. The Adrian Blackwood I observed then barely qualified as competent in basic combat fundamentals. Yet within weeks of awakening, you’re defeating Elite-rank opponents, creating innovative magical devices, and orchestrating complex tactical operations. That degree of transformation seems... implausible without prior concealment."
The pieces clicked together. She was questioning whether the "old Adrian" had been an elaborate act rather than genuine incompetence.
"Oh, that," I said, allowing a slight smile. "No, I wasn’t hiding my strength. I genuinely changed after my awakening. The bloodline transformation affected more than just my physical capabilities - it altered my entire perspective and priorities."
I met her gaze directly. "I realized that chasing after certain things simply wasn’t worth the effort anymore."
Her eyebrow moved fractionally - the only visible reaction to what was clearly a deliberate jab at her. Of course she understood the meaning behind my words. The old Adrian had pursued her relentlessly, making a fool of himself through transparent attempts to win her favor despite her obvious disinterest.
The silence stretched between us, charged with unspoken acknowledgment of that history.
Seraphina’s expression remained composed, though I detected subtle calculation behind her cold exterior. She was reassessing everything she thought she knew about me, recalibrating her understanding based on this new information.
"A convenient explanation," she finally said. "Bloodline awakenings can certainly cause personality shifts, though rarely to such dramatic degrees."
"Well, I guess I’m one of those rare cases," I countered with a smile on my face.
"Perhaps." She didn’t sound entirely convinced, but neither was she outright rejecting the explanation. "Your performance during the examination was... impressive. Particularly your strategic manipulation of the final confrontation."
"Thank you. Your duel with Emmet was also noteworthy. You defeated him despite the prolonged combat exhaustion."
Her eyes flickered with something that might have been respect. "You knocked me unconscious and triggered my elimination."
"Do you resent it?" I asked directly.
Seraphina considered the question seriously before responding. "No. You operated within the examination parameters and made tactically sound decisions. I lost because I allowed myself to be manipulated into an unsustainable combat situation. That’s a lesson worth learning, even at the cost of elimination."
The maturity of her response aligned with the novel’s portrayal of her character - someone who valued strength and thinking above petty grudges.
"Was there something specific you wanted from this conversation?" I asked. "Or was this purely reconnaissance?"
A ghost of a smile touched her lips - the first real expression beyond cold composure. "Reconnaissance, primarily. Kyle’s faction is trying to understand how you achieved such decisive victory. I volunteered to approach you directly rather than rely on second-hand speculation."
"And what will you report back?"
"Well, nothing new. You didn’t really say much, did you?"
Seraphina nodded, accepting the non-answer. "Fair enough. Thank you for your time, Adrian."
She walked away with the same grace she’d arrived with, leaving me to contemplate the implications of this unexpected conversation.​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​
After the conversation with Seraphina concluded, I continued toward Section G where all the specialized training facilities were located. The area was designated for intensive personal development, featuring various magical constructs and enchanted equipment designed to push students beyond their normal limits.
I approached the booking station and made an unusual request. "I need a training room with a Transcendent-rank combat dummy for two hours."
The attendant’s eyebrows rose slightly. "Young master Blackwood, you’re aware that’s significantly more expensive than the standard Elite-rank facilities? It’s five thousand points per hour."
"I’m aware. Proceed with the booking."
[-10,000 Points]
The substantial deduction barely fazed me given my recent examination rewards, though I could see other students nearby glancing over with obvious curiosity about why an Elite-rank student would pay premium rates for Transcendent-level training equipment.
The assigned room was noticeably larger and more heavily reinforced than standard facilities. The Transcendent-rank training dummy stood in the center - a magical construct that could withstand and measure attacks far beyond what Elite-rank equipment could handle.
I spent the next two hours in intensive training, pushing every aspect of my bloodline abilities to their absolute limits. Blood Control exercises focused on precision manipulation and maximum output. Supernatural Physique training involved extreme physical stress that would have crippled normal bodies. Blood Enhancement practice pushed my augmentation capabilities beyond comfortable thresholds.
The dummy’s integrated measurement systems tracked every strike, every technique application, every marginal improvement in my performance. The data would be valuable for analyzing my development trajectory.
Two hours later, drenched in sweat and breathing heavily from sustained exertion, I felt the familiar notifications pulse through my consciousness.
[Your Blood Control trait has reached level 4]
[Your Supernatural Physique trait has reached level 4]
[Your Blood Enhancement trait has reached level 4]
A smile formed on my face as I read through the notifications. All three of my primary traits had advanced simultaneously - an unprecedented achievement that represented weeks of accumulated effort finally bearing fruit. The improvements would be substantial, enhancing my combat effectiveness by a significant margin.
Before the training session, I had tested my maximum damage output against the Transcendent dummy to establish a baseline. The recorded value had been 21,500 damage units, the value was above anything any normal elite rank awakener could output. Anything above 20,000 units was known to be in the territory of transcendent-rank awakeners, even if it was on the lower end of the transcendent rank.
Now, with all my traits elevated to level 4, I was eager to see exactly how much stronger I had become.
"Time to test my new strength," I said aloud, a confident smile spreading across my face as I activated all my enhancements simultaneously and prepared to strike the dummy with everything I had.
Taking a deep breath, I steadied myself before activating my traits. The sword in my hand became enhanced, and multiple spears appeared above my head, waiting for my command to obliterate anything I wanted.

chapters.title: Chapter 140: Surprising Daily reward
chapters.content:
Chapter 140: Surprising Daily reward
My Blood Enhancement coursed through my muscles and bones, strengthening every fiber of my being beyond normal Elite-rank limitations. My Supernatural Physique amplified this effect further, my body becoming a weapon in itself.
The training dummy stood motionless, its magical sensors ready to measure the full force of what I was about to unleash.
Dash! Launch!
I exploded forward with supernatural speed, closing the distance in a blur of motion. The blood spears shot ahead like crimson missiles, their trajectories perfectly calculated to strike simultaneously with my sword.
BOOM! CRACK!
The spears slammed into the dummy’s reinforced surface with devastating force, each one creating explosive bursts of energy that would have shredded Elite-rank defenses. The magical construct absorbed the attacks, its measurement systems recording every unit of force.
SLASH!
My enhanced sword followed immediately behind, striking with the accumulated strength of all my traits working in concert. The blade carved through the dummy’s exterior with a sound like thunder, releasing a shockwave that rippled through the entire training room.
MEASUREMENT CALCULATING...
The dummy’s display began processing the damage data, numbers scrolling rapidly as magical sensors analyzed the multi-layered attack I had just executed.
[TOTAL DAMAGE OUTPUT: 24,725]
The number appeared in bright letters above the training construct, and I felt satisfaction wash over me at the concrete proof of my improvement.
I quickly ran the calculations in my head.
Previous maximum: 21,500.
Current result: 24,725.
The difference: 3,225 additional damage units.
"Not bad," I said aloud, unable to suppress my pleased smile. "A fifteen percent increase in overall combat power."
The improvement was substantial and represented far more than just numerical advantages. A fifteen percent boost meant I was no longer operating at the absolute bottom threshold of Transcendent-equivalent combat effectiveness. While I still wasn’t matching truly experienced Transcendent warriors, I had pushed beyond the level of newly advanced awakeners.
This meant facing opponents like the experienced Transcendent guards at my estate would now be genuinely competitive rather than overwhelming challenges. It meant my survival odds against higher-rank threats had improved meaningfully.
The level 4 advancement across all three primary traits had synergized perfectly, each enhancement amplifying the others to create exponential rather than merely additive improvements.
I dismissed the blood spears and deactivated my enhancements, feeling the familiar fatigue that came from maximum output but satisfied with the investment of time and points.
Ten thousand points for this training session had been expensive, but the measurable results justified every point spent.
My combat power continued climbing steadily toward levels that would allow me to face the challenges I knew were coming - challenges where Elite-rank strength would be
dangerously insufficient, but Transcendent-equivalent capabilities might just be enough to survive.
After my training session concluded and I’d taken a moment to catch my breath, my communication crystal began vibrating with an incoming call. I retrieved it from my pocket and channeled mana to establish the connection.
"Young Master Blackwood," came a professional voice I recognized as Gerald, one of the grand managers my father had assigned to oversee my business ventures. "I hope I’m not interrupting your studies."
"Not at all, Gerald. What’s the status report?"
"Excellent news, sir. The first production line for both the skateboard and crossbow systems has been completed and distributed as you know. We’ve sent samples to the twelve noble families currently operating under the Blackwood duchy’s commercial network for advertisement and market testing purposes."
Over the past week, I’d been working intensively on finalizing the prototypes for both inventions. The designs were now refined enough for mass production, and my father’s business infrastructure was proving invaluable for rapid commercialization.
"The initial reception has been extremely positive," Gerald continued with obvious enthusiasm. "Several families have already submitted advance orders based on the demonstration units. The skateboard in particular is generating significant interest among younger nobles and wealthy merchant families."
"What about the crossbow system?"
"Also promising, though the market is more specialized. Military officers and security forces are showing strong interest, particularly after seeing the mana-efficiency demonstrations."
"Good. And the second production line?"
"Currently in progress and should be ready for distribution by tomorrow. We’ve scaled up manufacturing capacity based on the projected demand from initial responses."
Gerald paused before addressing the pricing structure we’d discussed previously. "Regarding the final pricing you requested confirmation on - we’ve settled on two hundred golden coins per skateboard unit. The element-compatible arrows are priced at twenty golden coins each, and the complete crossbow system is eight hundred golden coins."
I considered these numbers carefully. Two hundred gold for a skateboard was substantial but reasonable given its magical enhancements and the target demographic of wealthy families. The crossbow at eight hundred gold positioned it as premium military equipment rather than mass-market goods, which aligned with my intentions.
"Those prices are acceptable," I confirmed. "Maintain quality standards above profit margins. I want these products building the Blackwood reputation for its superior craftsmanship."
"Understood, Young Master. I’ll send detailed sales reports weekly."
With production successfully underway and distribution channels established, a satisfied smile formed on my face. Based on conservative estimates, this business venture would generate several million golden coins if everything proceeded according to plan.
The skateboard’s accessibility and novelty would create massive demand among urban populations, while the crossbow system’s military applications would generate steady contracts with security forces and noble house guards. The profit margins were substantial given the relatively low material costs compared to the premium pricing.
Time passed with my usual routine of classes, training, and business coordination. When the familiar notification arrived indicating my daily reward was available, I activated it without particular expectations.
[Daily Login Available!]
[Would you like to claim your daily reward?]
[Yes | No]
I selected yes, and what materialized made me stare in complete confusion.
[Congratulations! You have received: Luxury Mansion Deed]
[Property Details: 5,000 square foot mansion, fully furnished, located within the capital city, District 3, Noble Quarter]
Looking at the reward before my eyes, I was genuinely perplexed.
I had just received an entire mansion instead of equipment or consumable items? This was unprecedented - the system had never provided real estate before.
I examined the official deed more carefully, noting the legal seals and property registration that confirmed legitimate ownership. What shocked me even more was the specific location. The mansion was actually situated within walking distance of the academy, positioned in one of the capital’s most prestigious districts.
This wasn’t some modest property in the outer rings. Properties in District 3’s Noble Quarter commanded astronomical prices due to proximity to the Royal Palace, academy access, and the concentration of influential families. A 5,000 square foot mansion in this location would cost millions of golden coins on the open market.
I decided to investigate immediately since the property was apparently only about ten minutes away on foot - or mere minutes via skateboard.
Retrieving my enhanced skateboard from storage, I hopped on and channeled mana into the propulsion system. The familiar smooth acceleration carried me through the academy gates and into the surrounding city streets.
Pedestrians still stared at the unusual device, but I’d grown accustomed to the attention. The skateboard had become something of a trademark for me around campus and the nearby districts.
Following the address listed on the deed, I navigated toward District 3’s exclusive residential areas, curious about what exactly the daily reward system had just granted me.
Following the address through increasingly upscale streets, I arrived at the specified location in District 3’s most prestigious section. When the mansion came into full view, recognition struck me immediately.
I knew this property.
My father had mentioned it during a recent conversation about expanding our family’s holdings in the capital. This mansion had been constructed just months ago by a master builder who specialized in creating residences for the highest nobility. The Duke had been seriously considering purchasing it to establish a permanent Blackwood presence near the Royal Palace and academy.
And now the deed sat in my possession, courtesy of the daily reward system.
Standing before the entrance, I couldn’t help but feel somewhat stunned. Although I hadn’t received combat equipment or magical items, this deed was worth its weight in gold several times over. Getting a property valued at multiple millions of golden coins was an extraordinary windfall.
The mansion itself was impressive without being ostentatious. The exterior featured clean white walls that gleamed in the afternoon sunlight, their pristine appearance showing the expert maintenance. The architecture followed classical design principles - balanced proportions, elegant columns flanking the main entrance, and large windows that would provide excellent natural lighting.
The grounds were equally impressive. A huge front garden stretched before the main building, carefully landscaped with manicured lawns and ornamental flower beds displaying seasonal blooms. A rocky pathway curved gracefully from the entrance gate to the front doors, bordered by meticulously trimmed hedges.
Trees had been strategically placed throughout the property to provide shade and aesthetic appeal without overwhelming the space. I could see a fountain in the central courtyard, its water features adding both visual interest and pleasant ambient sound.
The entire estate was enclosed by a tasteful wall that provided security without appearing fortress-like. The iron gates at the entrance bore no family crest yet, leaving them available for customization.
Five thousand square feet meant substantial interior space - enough for living quarters, entertainment areas, study rooms, and servant accommodations. This was a property designed for someone of significant social standing to host gatherings and conduct business while maintaining appropriate noble standards.
I approached the main entrance with the deed in hand, eager to see what the interior revealed.

chapters.title: Chapter 141: Using the Mask [1]
chapters.content:
Chapter 141: Using the Mask [1]
I unlocked the main entrance with the key that had materialized alongside the deed and stepped inside. The interior was as impressive as the exterior promised, though currently unfurnished and waiting for someone to make it their own.
The entrance hall was spacious and bright, with polished marble flooring that reflected the natural light streaming through tall windows. A grand staircase curved upward to the second floor, its elegant railings and wide steps designed to make an impression on visitors.
Moving through the ground floor, I discovered a large formal reception room that could easily accommodate fifty guests for social gatherings. The high ceilings and excellent acoustics made it perfect for entertaining, but as I stood in the empty space, a different vision emerged.
’This could be a cinema room,’ I thought, my mind racing with possibilities from my previous life. The dimensions were ideal - I could install tiered seating, projection equipment using magical crystals for illumination, and sound enhancement enchantments. A private theater where I could recreate the movie-watching experience from Earth would be both personally enjoyable and impressively novel for this world.
The only issue was the movies.
Where am I going to get movies in this world...I guess I might have to create my own then.
Continuing my exploration, I found what appeared to be designed as a formal dining hall. The room was massive, with space for banquet tables and elaborate serving arrangements. But another idea struck me as I examined the layout.
’This could become a modern entertainment lounge,’ I realized. Gaming tables, comfortable seating areas, perhaps even attempting to recreate arcade-style games using magical interfaces. The concepts from Earth could be adapted with this world’s magical technology.
The kitchen area was large and well-equipped with magical appliances for food preservation and preparation. At least this space could maintain its intended purpose, though I’d likely modernize the equipment with innovations inspired by Earth’s culinary technology.
Moving to the second floor, I discovered several bedroom suites, each with private bathing facilities. One particularly large room at the end of the corridor caught my attention immediately.
The space was enormous - probably intended as a master bedroom suite - but its attached bathroom area gave me ideas. The existing bathing chamber featured a sunken pool-style bath and excellent ventilation, but I could envision something far more luxurious.
’A proper spa and jacuzzi setup,’ I thought with growing excitement. Hot tubs with magical heating and water jets, separate sauna and steam rooms, massage areas with enchanted tables that could provide therapeutic benefits. This world had healing magic, but combining it with Earth’s wellness concepts could create something genuinely unique.
Another large room on the second floor appeared designed as a study or library, with built-in shelving and excellent natural lighting. This could remain relatively traditional, though I’d certainly stock it with both this world’s knowledge and whatever information I could recreate from my previous life.
The third floor surprised me with its open layout - a massive space that currently served no obvious purpose. Standing in the centre, I could imagine multiple possibilities.
’A personal training facility would be nice,’
The basement level offered even more potential. Several large, climate-controlled rooms that were probably intended for wine storage or food preservation could be repurposed entirely.
’Underground pool? Indoor sports court? Maybe even a magical workshop separate from the estate’s main areas,’ I considered. The possibilities seemed endless.
Walking back through the mansion, I felt genuine excitement building. This wasn’t just valuable real estate - this was an opportunity to create a modern living space that combined this world’s magical advantages with Earth’s comfort and entertainment concepts.
The daily reward system had given me a personal sanctuary where I could experiment, relax, and build something entirely unique that this world had never seen before.
After thoroughly checking the house and mentally cataloguing all the renovation possibilities, I decided to wait until night-time before pursuing another critical objective. My blood supplies were running dangerously low, and more importantly, my soul power accumulation had stagnated completely over the past week.
I needed to hunt.
When darkness fell properly over the capital, I slipped on the mask I kept for exactly these purposes. The enchanted item altered my appearance to show my original Earth features - a face that bore no resemblance to Adrian Blackwood and would prevent identification even if someone caught glimpses of me during the hunt.
The anonymity was essential. I couldn’t afford to have the Blackwood family’s enemies tracking my movements or identifying my hunting patterns. More practically, I needed fresh blood supplies and soul power absorption from defeated beasts, activities that were easier conducted without witnesses.
My standards had evolved significantly since my early awakening days. I no longer cared about Noble-rank or even low Elite-rank beasts - their blood was too weak, their hides too common, and their soul power too negligible to justify the effort. After tasting the potency of high Elite and Transcendent-rank blood, consuming lesser specimens felt almost disgusting by comparison.
I left the mansion through a side exit, immediately beginning a deliberately convoluted route through the capital’s back streets and alleyways.
Multiple turns, seemingly random direction changes, doubling back through covered passages, all designed to ensure nobody could follow my trail even with the mask concealing my identity.
My families’ enemies were sophisticated and patient. I wouldn’t make the mistake of underestimating their surveillance capabilities or assuming the mask alone provided sufficient protection.
After thirty minutes of careful navigation, I was confident no tail had managed to track me successfully. Only then did I retrieve my skateboard and accelerate toward the wilderness areas beyond the city walls.
I wasn’t worried about anyone catching me. It was night time, and the skateboards were no longer a thing only exclusive to me.
Zoom! Speed!
I blurred through the forest at enhanced velocity, my bloodline-improved senses easily navigating the dark terrain.
Lesser beasts appeared occasionally in my path, but I ignored them completely even when they were foolish enough to attack.
Growl! Lunge!
A Noble-rank wolf attempted to intercept me, clearly not recognizing my true strength since I kept my aura suppressed.

chapters.title: Chapter 144: Transcendent Prey
chapters.content:
Chapter 144: Transcendent Prey
Additionally, the probability of gaining a new echo or aspect from such concentrated combat was high. Mass elimination events often triggered bloodline evolution responses that single fights couldn’t match.
’A mosquito’s leg is still meat, no matter how small,’ I reminded myself with grim satisfaction.
Every Elite-rank Thornback represented incremental progress. Every high-Elite specimen added meaningful soul power. And the three Transcendent defenders would provide substantial advancement once I possessed the strength to defeat them.
This nest was a treasure trove waiting to be harvested, I just needed to become strong enough to claim it properly.
I left the Thornback nest area and continued deeper into the hunting grounds, searching for suitable prey that would provide meaningful soul power without requiring me to engage entire colonies or overwhelming numbers.
The forest grew denser as I moved further from civilization, the ambient mana concentration increasing to levels that would disorient inexperienced awakeners.
My senses detected various beast signatures throughout the territory. Though some were too weak to bother with, others already engaged in their own hunts. I needed something specific: a solitary Transcendent-rank creature that I could defeat through skill and tactics rather than overwhelming power.
After approximately twenty minutes of careful searching, I detected exactly what I needed.
This one gas a distinct aura... it’s powerful...
The magical signature emanated from a clearing ahead, carrying the unmistakable density of Transcendent rank but lacking the cooperative pack mentality that made group hunts so dangerous.
I approached cautiously, using the dense vegetation as cover while assessing my target.
What emerged into view was a massive wild yellow boar and "wild" barely captured its formidable nature.
The creature stood nearly six feet tall at the shoulder, its body covered in coarse yellow fur that seemed to shimmer with energy. Six powerful legs supported its massive body, each one ending in hooves that had carved deep gouges into the surrounding earth.
Two wickedly curved horns protruded from its skull, each one glowing faintly with the same yellow energy that permeated its fur. The beast radiated an aura of low Transcendent rank - strong enough to be dangerous, but within the range I could potentially defeat without complications.
With the assessment complete... I was ready to engage.
I stepped into the clearing deliberately, no longer concealing my presence. The yellow boar’s head snapped toward me immediately, its small eyes reflecting vigilance as it recognized a challenger.
SNORT!
The creature pawed at the ground with its front legs, creating small craters as it prepared to charge. Steam emanated from its nostrils, and the yellow aura around its body intensified visibly.
I drew my rare-rank sword and activated my blood enhancement, feeling the familiar surge of power flood through my system.
CHARGE!
That’s a bloodline trait!
The boar launched itself forward with explosive speed, its entire body engulfed in blazing yellow aura that left scorched earth in its wake. The charging skill transformed it into a living battering ram, capable of shattering stone and crushing steel.
I threw myself sideways at the last possible moment, the boar’s massive form thundering past my previous position. The displaced air felt like a physical blow, and I could smell the acrid scent of burned vegetation from its aura trail.
I counterattacked while it was recovering from the missed charge, my blade carving a deep gash along its flank. Blood sprayed from the wound, but the creature’s thick hide and supernatural constitution prevented it from being a critical injury.
ROAR!
The yellow boar spun with surprising agility for its size, and I saw energy gathering in its twin horns. The glow intensified dramatically as it prepared its second bloodline skill.
BLAST!
Twin beams of concentrated yellow energy erupted from the horns, converging on my position with devastating force. The attack carved through trees behind where I’d been standing, leaving smoking craters and shattered wood.
I barely avoided the energy blast by channeling maximum blood enhancement into my legs, moving faster than the boar could track. The beams swept across the clearing, searching for me as the creature tried to adjust its aim.
While the beast was focused on its energy attack, I activated my Blood Control trait with a goal in mind. Reaching out with invisible manipulation, I targeted the blood vessels behind one of the boar’s eyes and commanded them to rupture.
Pop
The yellow boar’s roar of pain echoed through the forest as its left eye exploded from internal pressure. Blood streamed down its face, and the energy blast from its horns cut off abruptly as the creature staggered from the sudden trauma.
But I wasn’t finished with my blood manipulation assault, with its body in shock, I doubled down on the effects.
I targeted the major blood vessels near its brain, creating temporary clots that disrupted circulation and oxygen flow. The technique was difficult, requiring precise control to create the stroke effect.
Stumble!
The boar’s legs buckled slightly as the artificial stroke took effect. Its movements became uncoordinated, its remaining eye unfocused as its brain struggled to function with disrupted blood flow.
That’s the opening! Strike Now!
I charged forward with my blade, targeting the creature’s exposed neck. This was my opportunity to land a decisive blow while it remained vulnerable.
SLASH!
My rare-rank sword carved through thick hide and muscle, opening a massive wound that sprayed Transcendent-rank blood across the clearing. The boar’s roar became a gurgling sound as the blade damaged critical structures.
But Transcendent beasts didn’t die easily. The yellow boar’s survival instincts kicked in, and it began channeling its bloodline power for another devastating charge despite its injuries. The yellow aura flared even brighter than before.
This is an all-or-nothing attack. It’s trying risking everything, it felt its impending doom.
The creature launched itself at me with suicidal determination, its entire body becoming a projectile of compressed energy and physical mass. Even with one eye destroyed and blood pouring from multiple wounds, the attack carried enough force to pulverize anything it connected with.
I could dodge again, but that would just prolong the fight.
Time to end this decisively.

chapters.title: Chapter 145: transcendent Prey [2]
chapters.content:
Chapter 145: transcendent Prey [2]
Null Strike.
WOOOOM!
The invisible sphere of absolute negation erupted around me at the precise moment of impact. The yellow boar’s devastating charge - all that accumulated energy, bloodline power, and desperate momentum - simply ceased to exist as it entered the technique’s radius.
The creature’s remaining eye widened in complete disbelief as its ultimate attack was negated entirely. The yellow aura surrounding its body flickered and died, leaving it vulnerable and exposed just feet away from my position.
I channeled every bit of blood enhancement into one decisive blow, my blade glowing crimson with concentrated power. The sword descended toward the stunned boar’s neck with supernatural speed and strength.
SLASH!
The enhanced strike severed the creature’s head completely, sending it tumbling across the clearing while the massive body collapsed with a ground-shaking impact.
I felt the familiar sensation of soul power flowing into me from the defeated Transcendent beast.
The essence was substantially more potent than Elite-rank absorption this single kill provided progress equivalent to dozens of peak elite creatures.
The combat had pushed me harder than recent fights, but the combination of blood manipulation, skill usage, and the Null Strike technique made it easier.
The yellow boar had never stood a real chance once I’d applied pressure from multiple angles.
I approached the corpse and began extracting its Transcendent-rank blood, the golden-yellow liquid filling multiple vials with precious enhancement material. This quality of blood would provide significant power when used for future combat or simply used for my feeding.
The hunt was proving successful. One Transcendent beast eliminated, valuable resources acquired, and meaningful soul power accumulated toward my eventual rank advancement.
I continued searching through the hunting grounds with renewed focus, my enhanced senses scanning for additional Transcendent-rank prey. The soul power from the yellow boar had been decent, but I needed more to make meaningful progress toward my goals.
Minutes later, I detected another promising signature - the distinctive aura pattern of a creature I actually recognized from my own studies.
There... perfect target...
A massive Stone-Hide Bear lumbered through a rocky clearing ahead, its body covered in natural armor that resembled granite plating. The creature stood nearly twelve feet tall when upright, with thick limbs that could crush boulders and claws that carved through solid rock.
Low Transcendent rank, just like the boar.
More importantly, I had studied this species during monster ecology classes. The Instructor had dedicated an entire lecture to Stone-Hide Bears, emphasizing their weaknesses alongside their formidable strengths.
They were really common because they were a part of one of the strongest clan in the surrounding area of the kingdom, the Bear clan.
Knees... that’s the key...
The creature’s massive body was supported by relatively vulnerable knee joints. Once those joints were compromised, the bear’s own weight became a liability rather than an asset. With both knees broken, the creature would be immobilized and easy to finish.
I didn’t waste time on long observation. Knowledge was power, and I possessed exactly what I needed to end this fight quickly.
I channeled a good blood from my vials, forming it into a massive mace - an effective bludgeoning weapon designed specifically for crushing things.
Whoosh!
I sent the blood mace hurtling through the air like a missile, guided by my [Blood Control] trait toward the bear’s right knee joint. The projectile moved with devastating velocity, ensuring a powerful impact.
CRACK!
Indeed, just like I expected. The impact was catastrophic. The mace struck the knee joint without fail, shattering bone and tearing ligaments with a sickening crunch that echoed through the clearing.
ROAR!
Thud!
The Stone-Hide Bear’s roar of agony was immediate as its right leg buckled completely. The massive creature lurched sideways, struggling to maintain balance on three remaining limbs while its shattered knee rendered one leg useless.
A gust of wind sent leaves flying as I charged forward while the beast was off-balance, my enhanced sword already positioned for a devastating follow-up strike. No time to let it recover or adapt to the injury.
SLASH!
My blade carved through the bear’s left knee with enhanced cutting power, slicing through the thick hide that normally resisted conventional weapons. I targeted the tendons and ligaments specifically, applying the anatomical knowledge from my studies.
Collapse!
With both knees destroyed, the Stone-Hide Bear crashed to the ground with tremendous force. Its massive body became a prison rather than an advantage - the creature simply couldn’t move effectively without functional legs.
It thrashed desperately, claws gouging the earth and jaws snapping at empty air, but the tactical situation was decided. An immobilized Transcendent beast was just a matter of execution.
I positioned myself carefully and drove my sword deep into the creature’s chest, piercing through the stone-like hide and penetrating directly into its heart. The strike would have been nearly impossible against a mobile opponent, but with the bear pinned by its own weight, it was straightforward.
The moment my blade penetrated the heart muscle, I activated my Blood Control trait with lethal intent. I manipulated the bear’s own blood, forcing it to flow at dramatically accelerated rates that the damaged heart couldn’t sustain.
The combination of physical damage and forced blood manipulation created catastrophic internal bleeding. The heart muscle, already pierced by my sword, couldn’t withstand the pressure I was applying.
Manipulating the blood inside the heart would have been almosg impossible had I not damaged it severely due to the difficulty of such an action.
Within seconds, the Stone-Hide Bear’s struggles weakened dramatically. Its roar faded to a gurgle, then silence, as massive internal hemorrhaging caused rapid system failure.
The familiar sensation of Transcendent-rank soul power flowing into me confirmed the kill. This essence combined with the yellow boar’s contribution, creating meaningful progress toward my eventual rank advancement.
The entire fight had lasted less than two minutes from initial engagement to final death. Academic study combined with tactical application had transformed what could have been a prolonged battle into a quick fight.
I withdrew my blade and began extracting the bear’s blood, noting the unusual thickness and earth-affinity properties that might prove useful for specific enhancement applications.
Before I attempted to extract the Stone-Hide Bear’s blood, a familiar notification pulsed through my consciousness, the sensation that always accompanied significant development.
[You have gained the aspect: Strong Body]

chapters.title: Chapter 146: Advancing in Rank!
chapters.content:
Chapter 146: Advancing in Rank!
[Aspect: Strong Body]
[Rank: Transcendent]
[Type: Passive]
[Details: Permanently increases the user’s physical durability and defensive capabilities by 25%. This enhancement affects skin resilience, bone density, muscle toughness, and internal organ protection. The aspect draws upon the Stone-Hide Bear’s natural armor properties, granting similar defensive characteristics without the mobility penalties that plagued the original creature. Unlike active aspects, this ability remains constantly active without mana expenditure or cooldown restrictions.]
A smile formed on my face as I processed the implications. This was exactly the kind of passive enhancement I needed - constant defensive improvement that would stack with my Stone Armor Echo for even greater protection.
The 25% increase meant attacks that would have caused serious injury would now only deal moderate damage, and blows that might have been fatal could potentially be survived.
The aspect’s origin from the Stone-Hide Bear was fitting. By studying and exploiting the creature’s weaknesses, I’d absorbed not just its soul power but also adapted its greatest strength into a form that suited my combat style perfectly.​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​
With the new Strong Body aspect providing constant defensive enhancement and the accumulated soul power from two Transcendent kills, I felt significantly more confident about eventually tackling the Thornback nest by myself.
The passive 25% durability increase would be crucial when facing swarm tactics from dozens of Elite-rank and transcendent rank spiders.
However, I could sense something else - a familiar sensation that indicated I was extremely close to advancing from mid-Elite rank to high-Elite rank. The soul power accumulation was nearly complete, just requiring one or two more substantial kills to trigger the breakthrough.
To maximize my chances of survival during the nest assault, I decided to eliminate another beast or two at Transcendent rank before attempting that dangerous operation. Every advantage mattered when facing overwhelming numbers, and entering at high-Elite rank with additional combat experience would be significantly better than rushing in prematurely.
Before continuing the hunt, I turned my attention to the Stone-Hide Bear’s corpse. Wasting valuable materials would be foolish when I had the time and storage capacity to harvest them properly.
I quickly dissected the massive creature with efficiency, my enhanced strength and sharp blade making the work manageable despite the tough hide. The bones were incredibly dense and strong - perfect base materials for crafting durable weapons or reinforced equipment. I extracted several large bone sections and stored them in my spatial ring.
The tendons and ligaments possessed unusual elasticity despite their thickness, suggesting applications in bowstrings or flexible armor components. I carefully removed the most intact specimens and preserved them properly.
Various organs showed promise for alchemical applications - the heart with its earth-affinity properties, certain glands that produced defensive secretions, even the creature’s blood had unique characteristics worth preserving beyond simple consumption.
The hide itself would fetch excellent prices or could be crafted into superior armor, though processing it properly would require specialized equipment I didn’t have in the field but as the son of a duke, that wasn’t an issur.
After approximately ten minutes of harvesting, I had collected everything valuable and portable. The remaining carcass would feed scavengers and return nutrients to the forest ecosystem.
Time to continue hunting... more prey needed...
I left the clearing and resumed my search for additional Transcendent-rank opponents, my enhanced senses scanning the surrounding territories while my newly acquired Strong Body aspect provided reassuring passive protection.
The night was still young, and I had more beasts to eliminate before dawn arrived.​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​
I continued through the hunting grounds with stealth, my enhanced senses leading me to a Transcendent-rank Flame Wolf that had been stalking prey near a volcanic spring.
A volcanic spring was a natural occurrence due to mana. The creature’s fire-based abilities made it dangerous to others, but it wasn’t for me.
The fight was brief but intense, the wolf’s flames scorched the surrounding vegetation, but I used Blood Control to create internal disruptions that weakened its coordination. A well-timed Null Strike negated its most powerful fire blast, and my sword found its throat before it could recover.
Soul power absorption...
The Transcendent essence flowed into me, and I felt something slowly change within my core. The accumulated soul power from three Transcendent beasts was about to trigger the breakthrough I’d been sensing.
[You have advanced to High Elite Rank]
The transformation was immediate and profound. My body felt stronger, my mana reserves deepened, and my bloodline traits operated with noticeably greater efficiency. The rank advancement represented a meaningful leap in overall capability.
After advancing it was time to return to the nest, I had spiders to eliminate.
On my way back, I encountered peak Elite-rank beasts, as I fought I realized something significant. I was now strong enough to directly target and rupture their hearts without worrying about mana.
